trello_data.desc:
Ethixxx was a social enterprise startup my partner founded. It was intended to provide a shame-free platform for ethically produced adult content: with the goal of reducing the manipulative business practices of the adult industry and reducing the incidence of pornography addiction. 

Ethixxx was to achieve this by creating a site with a mixture of adult films, behind-the-scenes content (e.g. interviews, articles), and educational material. The revenue model was to be a combination of video sales and a premium advertising network that would only display values-aligned content. 

My role was to help craft the initial product design—imagining what a non-sleazy adult site would look like. It included features such as trigger warnings such that survivors of abuse could avoid content that could retraumatize them. 

We got to the mockup stage and received an interview with the prestigious YCombinator Fellowship programme. 

Ethixxx was put on the back-burner after my partner entered the Enspiral Dev Academy. 

---

_**2016.** Product design & prototyping. Business development. Advisory. _
trello_data.name: Ethixxx

trello_data.desc:
Trailblazer maps out your journey across the web. Used when you're doing research, Trailblazer creates maps that put your train of thought in front of you. When you pause your research session, you come back to a map, rather than a row of browser tabs or folder of bookmarks. 

Trailblazer emerged in the thick of Lightning Lab when we saw nothing but rows of browser tabs open on every computer. After researching the tab problem, we realised that a vast majority of tabs are left open to "save your place" while researching, and we developed a mapping tool to remove this need. 

I stepped back from hands-on design in this role to focus on setting the direction of the team building the product.

We marketed it initially to secondary education, where Trailblazer allows teachers or mentors assess the quality of questions students are asking when they perform research. 

We also did some pretty fun educational Minecraft projects with students—such as a national competition with over 300 entrants that was judged on quality of build and research. 

I left Trailblazer in early 2016 to pursue other projects. Matt Kennedy, current CEO, has now open-sourced it. You can grab it over at [Trailblazer.io](http://trailblazer.io/).

---

_**2014 – 2016.** Product vision and direction. Stakeholder interviews. Project Management. Educational projects. Marketing. Web design/development. Writing._
trello_data.name: Trailblazer

trello_data.desc:
Twingl, and its follow up, Trailblazer, sprang from the ashes of Commonplace after Startup Weekend Wellington 2013. The vision was to augment intelligence by creating tools to let you emergently organise and rediscover the information you consumed. There was a real transhumanist vision behind it: the dream was simply being able to "pluck" off a constellation of thoughts and give them to someone else. 

We built 6 different product experiments centred around reading, annotating, and writing. Our final experiment, simply called Twingl, was an annotation tool for the web, which allowed you to link highlights together, so structure would emerge bottom-up, rather than top down by categories or tags. 

After the Lightning Lab accelerator in 2014, we discontinued work on our annotation tools in favour of Trailblazer, which had a more obvious path to market. 

---

_**2013 – 2014.** Product Design. Branding/Storytelling. Writing. Front-end development. Led the company._
trello_data.name: Twingl

trello_data.desc:
Commonplace was a project produced for my final year of university. It was designed to be a digital "commonplace book"—a compendium of all the things you're reading or working on. You could create collections of articles, images and notes—all of which you could annotate. 

This all sprang out of a frustration at the course requirement of maintaining a paper workbook showing our thought process and gathered research. The workbooks themselves were super useful—like a time portal to what you were thinking about 3 or 6 months ago—but the process of creating, maintaining and reordering them was laborious.

In hindsight, Commonplace wasn't very effective at the goal ofexternalising the process of developing thoughts. I made all the classic mistakes like feature-creep and lost vision for the product. It turned out to be more useful for generating moodboards.

Commonplace, after being pitched at a Startup Weekend, turned into a company called Twingl. We would spend the next three years building experiments in ways we can store knowledge outside of our heads. 

Commonplace was designed to place the content first, and so I rolled with a pretty simple, Swiss-inspired aesthetic. (And, to be honest, I was riding a Müller-Brockmann fetish at the time as well.)

---

_**2011 – 2012.** Product Design. Writing. Front-End Development. (Backbone.js)_

---
